name: Kepler-430
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-430 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-430 is a star with 1.17 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.49 times its radius. It is located 3073.24 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-430 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-430 b

Kepler-430 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2015-02. Its semi-major axis is 0.22 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 35.97 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-430.

The mass of Kepler-430 b is 16.29 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-430 b is 3.25 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-430 b is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.

Kepler-430 c

Kepler-430 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2015-02. Its semi-major axis is 0.48 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 110.98 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-430.

The mass of Kepler-430 c is 3.91 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-430 c is 1.75 that of Earth. At 3.91 Earth masses, Kepler-430 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-430, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
